pros:
Christ centered
Some great people do work there

Poor pay, no raises for over 5 years
Have taken away ability to have a conference paid at least partially 
Cut amount going to TIAA credit from 10% to 3%
Increased cost of health insurance but increased deductible 
Unfair in decision making
Supervisors play favorites 
It is ALL about money
Poor decisions made when starting a football team. They spent a ton of money on this, a stadium, and a marching band but cut your employees benefits and no raises, really? Your employees are your most important commodity. 
Certain leaders railroad employees out of the University because she doesn’t like some people. I saw this multiple times during my employment there.

review_title: Good school, but wonky personnel processes
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Good program, 5-week course, rigorous program. Students have to work for their grades.
cons:
Courses are pre-setu p - no flexibility on content.
Wonky evaluation system. My supervisor turned in the correct data from my course and would not fix it. This gave me a lower rating which caused me to not get additional classes.
They also seem to have a horrible hiring process - I know someone they hired but then never gave them a course. They don't seem to have a handle on the amount of adjuncts they actually need.
Pay is lower than at other schools.

review_title: We lose the best people to other companies while we just stagnate
job_title: Enrollment Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: Adoption and Down Payment Benefits are good. My peers are good people and some of the AD's are great.
cons: Pretty much everything else. The pay is terrible compared to other schools in online enrollment and we've lost a ton of people to jobs that will pay them a lot more and they get to stay at home. The city has fallen apart and it is hard to see how bad it has gotten. We've had boss after boss after boss in AES enrollment and they can't keep someone in the job. The good old boys (and girls) club here is strong and if you come in from anywhere else you are treated like an outsider. If you want to change or improve anything you have to fight for it, knowing you probably won't win. We finally had a boss that taught us how to do our jobs and gave us support and today he's leaving for another job that will probably pay better and actually want to get better. We finally were going somewhere and now we're stuck with out-of-touch upper management who like to dress up as Santa to win points and a secretary who runs him.

review_title: great job, friendly coworkers and supervisors

review_title: Great gig for extra spending money
pros: Teaching with IWU as adjunct faculty provides for lots of flexibility.  This teaching position allows me to help adult students earn their degree while working full-time and having a family.  The curriculum is provided so the time commitment is less than you would expect.  I teach both online and at a couple of the satellite campuses.  The face to face interaction in the classroom is rewarding.  The technology used for the online learning culture is not bad.  It is refreshing to be able to share my faith in the classroom and know that it is expected, not frowned upon.  A great university with a wonderful mission.
cons: Class sizes have been getting very large lately which is time consuming if you teach properly.  Doesn't pay great now that the commitment has increased.  When the classes were smaller, the pay seemed to match the time commitment better.

review_title: Poor Decision-Making; Poor Treatment of Employees
pros: Flexible work-from home hours as an adjunct professor.  Great opportunity to work directly with students.  Students are often very pleasant and enjoyable.
cons:
There have been so many changes in management that I don't even know who the boss is any more.  I used to teach in excess of 20 classes a year (when the full time staff taught less than half of that) and was a respected professor...very highly rated by students and management alike.  

The pay is terrible - about $1300 a class.  When Obamacare came into being, IWU chose to simply cut all the adjunct classes WAY down (ruining the livelihoods of many of their professors) instead of asking who already HAD insurance (for example, from a spouse).  

That was a pretty chicken methodology to choose - instead of honoring the MAJOR hours that many of the adjunct professors were teaching.  They also stopped letting adjuncts teach in more than one program/department - and chose "the first" department that they taught in as "the department that one had to stay with."  

This became a problem for many, because as particular programs crashed/had lower student enrollment, classes were cut even more - and sometimes the second department still had a need for professors. 

There were so many sudden management changes that eventually I couldn't even figure out who my boss was.  I haven't taught a class there for over a year because they aren't using adjuncts at all in my current department (and they had to lay off multiple full-time professors). 

Although I technically "work" there - I clearly don't work there anymore.  This is not an institution that has its head on straight - or its eyes on the Lord.  I consider their insurance decision ungodly and harmful to their previously loyal adjunct professors.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Marion, IN
pros: IWU offers great benefits for faculty, including 10% of your salary in a retirement fund. Most employees are warm and friendly Christians, who do their best to support each other and students.
cons: The administration is sometimes less concerned with the experiences and input of employees than with numbers and retention, basically the bottom dollar. Obviously the university needs to stay competitive, but there have been decisions made that are somewhat heavy handed, especially where middle management is concerned. Overall, however, there are great ethics at work there and people trying to walk out their faith in a real way, leading and teaching students.

pros: They are very flexible for full time students and provide a variety of opportunities to succeed. They work as a team and truly try to better you as person.
cons: The pay is not ideal, but I was a student when working there. It inhibits you to get used to what the real workplace would be like because they tend to be more conscious that you are a student.

review_title: Good people, but overall low job satisfaction
pros: Quality people. Management and leadership generally seem to care overall. Good benefits/PTO. Upper leadership has good vision and is trying to take steps to improve the overall environment. Because of the leadership's vision for the future, I am giving a three-star review. Otherwise it would be a two-star.
cons: Very little chance for advancement/pay increase. Sometime it can seem that unless you are part of the "in crowd" and are friends with upper leadership, you probably won't get considered for advancement. It consistently appears that positions are filled by who leadership had in mind up front, but opened the job up to everyone to keep up appearances of being fair. Turnover is high in the enrollment department. Numerous quality individuals have left recently, but only a couple of them are being replaced. The rest of us are expected to take up the slack. On my team alone, 2 people have had to go on high blood pressure meds since starting in the position less than 2 years ago. Very stressful. I don't believe we are compensated fairly for the amount of work expected of us. I believe lower-level management want to help us, but the administrative expectations put on them are ridiculous. They don't have time to appropriately coach their teams. Other universities have 2 managers per team, a coaching manager and administrative manager. IWU isn't hearing it. So our managers are essentially expected to do two jobs. VASTLY understaffed in other departments. The university wants to grow, but doesn't seem to want to invest in the personnel to get us there successfully. As it is now, we struggle to get a lot of students through the process of enrollment because of under-staffing issues, let alone increasing the number of students getting processed.

review_title: Good intentions, but chaotic work system
pros: Christian setting, nice facilities, good benefits, pleasant work place
cons: The University continues to shift leadership and organizational structure year after year with no adherence to any strong plan or mission.  It is discouraging to be a part of and to see the impact it has on our community and our students.  Male dominated & the few women leaders are quickly criticized if they are assertive.

pros: Sincere, visionary leaders and employees who really care about making it a Christ-centered culture for students. Tends to be a place where employees are seen as whole people, and coworkers care about each other.
cons: Culture, expectations, and pay vary wildly by the team and area where you work. Some teams have issues with sexism/ "old boys club" mentality, others are led by women at the highest levels. Even this seems to be getting better, though.

cons: There aren't too many cons to a student assistant position. However, the other offices may be different, but my office is wonderful. Everyone is very friendly and helpful! The only con would be the low pay.

pros: Good people to work with, great pay, 100% tuition reimbursement for undergrad programs, tuition program for grad programs, 8% 401K contribution from employer. 3 weeks vacation from start.
cons: Insurance is good but a little high, but it is everywhere else too. Not much else that's bad! I would highly recommend this non profit.

review_title: great culture, poor pay, constantly overloaded
